{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3713900,"name":"FredK","username":"FredK","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/f/71e660/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-08-14T14:02:36.514Z","cooked":"

I’m always a bit concerned with quality of items bought from online vendors (Amazon, Alibaba, etc). Does anyone have a source of lever wire connectors (22-24 gauge) that they have had success with? Besides WCP.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-08-14T14:02:36.514Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":135,"readers_count":134,"score":52.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":505283,"topic_slug":"looking-for-quality-source-of-can-lever-wire-connectors","display_username":"FredK","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31768,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/looking-for-quality-source-of-can-lever-wire-connectors/505283/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3715233,"name":"paulonis","username":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-08-15T00:23:32.453Z","cooked":"

The Wago 221-412 connectors are spec’d down to 24 AWG and have held 22 AWG CAN wire securely in my experience. They don’t have an ideal form factor, but I’d say that is a problem even for inline lever connectors. They are all pretty bulky for CAN.

I haven’t had an issue with these inline wago lever locks, they are only rated to grip down to 20AWG.

https://www.menards.com/main/electrical/electrical-tools-accessories/terminals-connectors/inline-wire-connectors/wago-lever-nuts-reg-2-wire-20-12-awg-inline-connector-10-count/60511893/p-1642874302380438-c-6445.htm?exp=false

Although I am sure some of the success I have seen is due to things like wire management and strain relief.

YMMV

See 3630 \ 3891 solutions for can wiring:

What Are the Best Practices for a Reliable CAN Bus Setup? Electrical
We ended up using these same connector with great success! This year was the first year for 3630 and 3891 that we were not bricked due to wiring issues. Most of the credit goes toward how we wired our can bus. Yes we remained dedicated to the daisy-chain topology, except we pushed the limit a little bit. We transformed our wiring practices from a low-detectability - Single point of failure (labelled in the below highly technical wiring CAD as “old school”). Each box is a kraken/cancoder. […
amazon.com

GKEEMARS 65 Pcs Compact Splicing Wire Connectors Assortment Pack, Quick Wiring...

GKEEMARS 65 Pcs Compact Splicing Wire Connectors Assortment Pack, Quick Wiring Connector for AWG 28-12: Amazon.com: Tools & Home Improvement

$28.98
